summary: The document outlines a series of reconnaissance missions from 20 June to 10 July 1956, aimed at penetrating Soviet Bloc air defense systems. It reveals the Soviet Union's awareness and subsequent countermeasures, such as deploying MIG-19 aircraft and enhancing their air defense warning system. These missions yielded valuable intelligence on Soviet radar systems and air defense capabilities, including the discovery of new radar sites and technologies.
key_findings: By 5 July 1956, the Soviet Union was aware of the reconnaissance missions and responded with countermeasures, including grounding civil flights and deploying MIG-19 aircraft.
An improvement in the Soviet air defense system's performance was noted by 9 July 1956, with enhanced tracking and altitude reporting capabilities.
The missions led to the identification of 213 new Soviet radar sites, with indications of more sites existing beyond the scope of the gathered intelligence.
The reconnaissance efforts may have prompted the Soviet Union to introduce advanced radar technologies, such as ROCK CAKEs.
